caseTitle: FAUSTINA APPIAH v. MRS. IRENE DE BORDES
summary: In Faustina Appiah v. Mrs. Irene de Bordes, the Court of Appeal of Ghana overturned a High Court decision that invalidated a will due to disputed signature authenticity. The testator, Harold Smith Boatin, executed a will on February 8, 1988, three weeks before his death, with two attesting witnesses and a secretary present. The trial court rejected the will based on a handwriting expert's opinion that the signature differed from known samples, particularly due to a line beneath it. However, the Court of Appeal found that the trial judge erred in disregarding the credible, unchallenged testimony of the attesting witnesses and the will's proper execution. The appellate court emphasized that attestation evidence carries significant weight and that minor signature variations do not invalidate a will when eyewitness accounts confirm due execution. The appeal was allowed, and the will was declared valid.
citations: In Re Cole (Decd): Cudgoy v. Cole, [1977] 2 G.L.R. 315
Sasu v. White Cross Insurance Co. Ltd. [1960] G.L.R. 4
In the Estate of Fuld (No.3); Hartley v. Fuld [1968] P. 675
rationaleHighlights: The trial judge erred in law by ignoring unchallenged eyewitness testimony of attesting witnesses who confirmed the testator's signature.
Minor discrepancies in signatures do not override credible evidence of due execution.
The burden of proof shifted to the defendant after the plaintiff established proper attestation.
Expert handwriting evidence must be considered cautiously and cannot override direct observation.
The maxim 'omnis presumuntur rite acta' applies where a will appears properly executed.
The testator was found to have had testamentary capacity based on contemporaneous correspondence.
The court-appointed expert was impartial but his opinion was not decisive in light of attestation evidence.
Proper form and attestation are substantive safeguards against fraud in will-making.
